awd_titl_txt: Dynamics of Ultracold Neutral Plasmas in the First 100 NS
awd_abstract_narration:
The experiments to be done in this work will push the frontier of strongly coupled neutral systems. Ultracold neutral plasmas provide an idealized system in which to probe the effects of many-body interactions and particle correlations. These correlations are predicted to change the collective behavior of dense energetic plasmas. They are also predicted to alter fundamental atomic processes in plasmas such as ion thermalization, three-body recombination, and collisional ionization. Ultra-cold neutral plasmas occupy a unique place in phase space, at the confluence of atomic, plasma, and condensed matter physics. We create these plasmas by exciting laser-cooled atoms to states near the ionization limit. The initial density, ion temperature, and electron temperature are independently controlled with high precision. High-resolution spectroscopic tools are used to diagnose the plasma state. These studies of ultracold neutral plasmas directly contribute to our understanding other strongly coupled systems. 

The broader impacts of this work are the training of undergraduate and graduate students in atomic physics. The PI has a strong track record of mentoring undergraduate and graduate students, helping them present their own reseach national meetings, and co-authoring peer-reviewed publications with them. This work also improves science education outside of BYU. This project will continue to recruit high school teachers as summertime research assistants and to interact with BYU's REU/RET program. Some of the laser facilities will continue to be used in a graduate course in Laser Physics. The PI also hosts occasional elementary school tours, demonstrating some of the beautiful and exciting properties of lasers to young and budding scientists. The research will be important to a number of areas in science and technology. Strong coupling occurs in some astrophysical environments, high energy density plasmas, quark-gluon plasmas, the BEC/BCS crossover, the Mott-insulator transition, non-neutral and dusty plasmas, and other systems. Calculations in these systems are difficult because of the wide range of important time scales. These benchmark measurements can be used to guide simulations in these systems.

The primary focus of our research under NSF grant 0969856 was to study how ions approach thermal equilibrium on the shortest time scales in "ultracold" neutral plasmas. These ultracold plasmas are strongly coupled, meaning that the nearest-neighbor Coulomb potential energy of these charged particles is approximately equal to the kinetic energy of the electrons and ions in the plasma. The ratio of these energies is defined as Gamma, and it is an indicator of the strength of many-body interactions in the plasma. The parameter Gamma can be used to characterize plasmas over a wide range of density and temperature. Plasma transport properties scale with Gamma, making it possible for us to use low-density plasmas with temperatures near absolute zero to extend our knowledge of properties of fusion-class plasmas, even though the temperature and density in those plasmas are many orders of magnitude higher. Because our plasmas are so cold, we can use precision laser spectroscopy to evaluate the approach to equilibrium under tightly controlled experimental conditions. It is hoped that with this knowledge, it will be possible to manipulate the ion velocity distribution to better understand collisions and other interactions in this exotic plasma regime.

Here are our key findings during the past three years.

  1. Electron screening slows down disorder-induced heating. In our 2011 paper ``Density and temperature scaling of disorder-induced heating in ultracold plasmas,'' [ S. D. Bergeson, A. Denning, M. Lyon, and F. Robicheaux, Phys. Rev. A 83, 023409 (2011)], we studied how the characteristic time scale for disorder-induced heating (DIH) changed with plasma density and electron temperature. In a collaboration with Francis Robicheaux, we showed that the characteristic DIH time is lengthened when electron shielding is important. We showed that this characteristic time is longer than what is described by just the nearest-neighbor acceleration and shorter than the time required to establish plasma mode oscillations. We derived an expression for finding the equilibrium ion temperature as a function of the electron screening length.
  2. Theory poorly predicts the amount of DIH slowing. In another 2011 paper ``The influence of electron screening on disorder-induced heating,'' [M. Lyon and S. Bergeson, J. Phys. B 44, 184014 (2011)] we expanded our spectroscopy capabilities so that we could more accurately determine the ion rms velocity in our plasmas. We pointed out that the ions were equilibrating when the electrons are strongly coupled. In this regime of "nonideal plasmas" we have less than one particle per Debye sphere. We compared the ion heating rate to a calculation by Michael Murillo at LANL and found only qualitative agreement.
  3. ``Ultracold'' physics at room temperature. In our 2012 paper ``Ultracold neutral plasmas at room temperature,'' [N. Heilmann, J. B. Peatross, and S. D. Bergeson, Phys. Rev. Lett. 109, 035002 (2012)], we showed that a plasma generated by a fs-duration "ultrafast" laser pulse focused into a room-temperature jet has many of the same characteristics as our ultracold neutral plasmas. The main similarity is that the ion temperature is determined by the plasma density through DIH. In addition, the plasma expansion is driven by electron pressure, and depending on the density and the initial size of the plasma, the plasma expands faster than the electron-ion equilibration time.
  4. Electron shielding always gives Gamma=1, even if the ions are very cold. Our most recent 2013 paper ``Limit of Limit of strong ion coupling due to electron shielding,'' [M. Lyon, S. D.
